awd_titl_txt: Developing Integrative Manufacturing and Production Engineering Curricula That Leverage Data Science
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will contribute to the national need for well-educated engineers and technicians in production engineering.  It will do so by developing modular courses in data science for production engineering.  These courses will be developed by Northeastern University in collaboration with MassBay Community College, four Manufacturing USA institutes, and three industry partners. The overall goal of the project is to design, develop, and deploy sustainable, online courses and curricula that bridge the production engineering-oriented data science skills gap of incumbent professional engineers and entering engineers and technicians.  The program will address four groups of learners: working professionals who need to upgrade their data science skills; career-transitioning learners without manufacturing backgrounds; undergraduates who wish to minor in data science for production engineering; and two-year community college students preparing for either entering the workforce or a four-year college program.  The project plans to develop: 1. A modular production engineering-oriented data science curriculum with seven courses that, in turn, are comprised of modules;  2. An online course/module recommendation system to help students determine which course or module best meets their needs and current skillset; 3. Credentials including certificates and a minor in data science for production engineering.  The project aims to address the production engineering-oriented data science skills gap, thus helping to meet the demand for workers in manufacturing, which is estimated to have at least two million unfilled positions between 2018 and 2028.

The project has the following objectives:  1. Identify the data science skills gap of current and future production engineering workforce; 2. Develop modular courses enabled by interactive multimedia content with active learning via on-line labs; 3. Develop a course-module recommender system; 4. Deploy developed courses through the Open edX platform and Jupyter Notebooks; 5. Study the effectiveness of online courses using theories and tools of learning science; and 6. Rigorously evaluate program objectives and outcomes via the expertise of an external evaluator.  The project will address research questions that align with the project objectives, such as whether learners? prior knowledge helps or hinders learning and what mechanisms best help learners acquire self-directed learning skills. The research component of the project will include a Design Based Research approach, which includes iterative formative assessment that drives ongoing curricular improvements.  Research data will include results from assessments of the fidelity of the courses/curricula in meeting industry needs, student performance data, and data from surveys and psychometric assessments. The curriculum will be designed to accommodate students with differing needs by providing multiple credentialing opportunities from course auditing, certificates in data science for production engineering and applied data science for production engineering, and a college-level minor.  

This project is funded by NSF's EHR Core Research: Production Engineering Education and Research (ECR: PEER) program, which seeks to improve the education of future and current professionals in production engineering. It also aims to study the effectiveness of the innovative educational strategies adopted by these projects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
OVERVIEW

This project, funded in 2019 through NSF's ECR PEER program with a total award of $2 million, aimed to enhance education and workforce training by developing and evaluating an innovative, modular online course curriculum. The initiative sought to equip learners with high-demand skills aligned with Industry 4.0 production environments and smart manufacturing. This project achieved the following goals: Designed a modular online curriculum using design principles and methodologies; built a course-module recommendation system to help learners personalize course selection; deployed curriculum and course modules for online learners; conducted research to discover nsights of online learning; evaluated program objectives to assess the program success.

The project team in collaboration with online course designer team from Odonnel Learn to developed eight online courses identified as necessary for retooling or upgrading the workforce for smart manufacturing. The project partners, the Oregon State University (OSU) and the MassBay Community College (MassBay), provided input on designing the course curricula appropriate for working professionals and community college students. Northeastern University subject matter experts have designed and developed modular course content.

MAJOR ACCOMPLISHMENTS

1. Modular Curriculum Development and Online Delivery
Eight online courses were developed and deployed. Northeastern University offers them as digital badges accessible via the project website: https://impel.sites.northeastern.edu/. The following are the courses developed:

  • IE 0400: Ethics, Privacy, and Cybersecurity
  • IE 0405: Computation and Visualization
  • IE 0410: Data Management for Analytics
  • IE 0415: Algorithms and Optimization
  • IE 0420: Data Analytics
  • IE 0425: Sensor Analytics
  • IE 0430: Cybermanufacturing Systems
  • IE 0435: Robotics and Automation

2. AI-Powered Course Recommendation System
The project team developed an AI-driven, personalized course recommendation system using OpenAI's GPT-4 API. This system employs Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) to suggest tailored learning pathways based on user goals, experience, and career interests. Findings from this development will be documented in the paper accepted for publication in the 2025 American Society for Engineering Education (ASEE) Conference proceedings.

3. Workforce Skills Gap Analysis
The project team conducted a comprehensive data-driven analysis of skills and knowledge gaps in the manufacturing workforce utilizing the Emsi Labor Market Analytics database. This study identified the critical skills and domain knowledge required for data science-related jobs that are highly in demand in today's and future advanced and intelligent manufacturing industry. Findings, published in a peer-reviewed journal, guide curriculum design to align educational content with workforce demands.

4. Research on Knowledge Trends in Manufacturing
Using Keyword Co-occurrence Network (KCN) methods, the project team analyzed two decades of manufacturing literature to map data science-related keywords to Industry 4.0 pillars, such as IoT, cloud computing, and cyber manufacturing. Results, published in a journal, help the manufacturing community identify research trends and education and training needs for emerging technologies in intelligent manufacturing.

5. Evaluation and Student Pilot Testing
The project team implemented a comprehensive evaluation strategy, including blueprint reviews, student feedback, and pilot testing. OSU led the evaluation, conducting studies with 19 undergraduate students and gathering insights through surveys and interviews. Key evaluation questions addressed learning engagement, knowledge transfer, course design, and alignment with workforce needs.

6. Industry and Community College Engagement

  • OSU team engaged with industry experts from GE, Johnson & Johnson, and CESMII to validate curriculum relevance and provide course design feedback.
  • A quasi-Delphi study with MassBay and industry partners contributed to a summative evaluation report, summarizing outcomes, challenges, and lessons learned.
  • MassBay faculty helped ensure curriculum alignment with community college standards.

 

7. Student Involvement
Three Ph.D. and two Master's students were supported by this project. These students were trained in research methods, data science applications in manufacturing, research discussion and presentation, project operations, and technical paper writing.

BROADER IMPACTS

This project contributes significantly to the national agenda for workforce development in smart manufacturing. It supports:

  • Broader access to high-quality online education for non-traditional learners and working professionals.
  • Alignment of academic curricula with evolving manufacturing industry workforce needs.
  • Integration of cutting-edge AI tools into education for personalized selection of course modules to meet learners' professional development goals.
  • Insight into skills demand and knowledge trends in smart manufacturing to guide curricula development for evolving workforce needs.

The project also fostered collaboration between universities, community colleges, and industry partners, ensuring that educational innovations are both academically rigorous and practically relevant.

DISSEMINATION

Results and course modules were shared at the "Manufacturing Future of Work Symposium" hosted at MassBay. The event engaged 45 participants from academia, industry, and government, facilitating knowledge exchange and collaboration. The results were also shared at the ASEE conferences. The scholarly work on skills and knowledge gaps in smart manufacturing workforce and the manufacturing research and technology trends that inform workforce development were made available to broader audiences through publications in peer-reviewed journals. In collaboration with Pix Videos Production Company, the project team developed a short animation video to promote the project to a broader audience.


Last Modified: 04/11/2025
Modified by: Sagar V Kamarthi
